reasoning: The critique targets a real premise used in the paper’s bounded-“universal value” discussion: if most value is outside humanity’s influence (e.g., many alien moral patients), then bounded concave views become approximately linear over our action range, supporting “fussiness.” If that empirical/cosmological premise weakens, that sub-argument weakens too (moderate centrality). However, the paper’s overall “no easy eutopia” conclusion is supported by multiple independent routes (eutopian fragility/multiplicativity; unbounded linear views; bounded difference-making fussy cases), so undermining the alien-civilizations move does not collapse the position (centrality well below 0.5). The critique’s refutation strength is limited: it relies on speculative future evidence (2032 null technosignatures) and assumes that would substantially change the ‘tiny marginal impact’ claim; plus the paper frames the alien-civilization point conditionally (“If so…”), not as a fixed assumption. Still, it insightfully notes that the practical upshot is contingent and would warrant explicit robustness/sensitivity analysis. Clarity is high. Some narrative about institutional cascades/ecosystem collapse is more illustrative than necessary, creating moderate dead weight. It largely stays focused on one issue.
title: The paper’s linear “marginalism” hinges on an empirically fragile big-universe premise
